content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

Sure, here is an example of how you can do it in Julia:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits{T<:AbstractFloat}
    value::T
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, x::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, "$(x.value) $(x.unit)")
end
```

In this code, a `FloatWithUnits` struct is defined to contain both a floating-point value and a string for the unit of measurement. A show function is implemented using Julia's built-in IO protocol which automatically calls whenever we print an instance of FloatWithUnits. The function concatenates the value and unit with a space.
